G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, codified at G.L. c. 186, § 14, which protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.

General Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so “shall also be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and thus be liable for constructive eviction, where conditions substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment and are within the landlord’s control, even absent an intent to deprive. The opinion emphasizes that a breach may arise from what the landlord "failed to do" when the disturbing condition is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s arrangements and the landlord has the ability to correct it. This aligns with the proposition that failure to correct substantial, known interferences can constitute a breach.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…"

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Similarly, in *Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–52, the Court held that a landlord’s repeated failure to adequately repair leaky ceilings and water damage, causing continuing problems for the tenant, supported a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment and the award of statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion does not involve leaky ceilings, water damage, or any repair issues; it concerns whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The Court uses prior cases (including ones about failure to repair defects) as examples, but Al‑Ziab itself neither finds a breach of quiet enjoyment nor awards statutory damages; it vacates the § 14 fee award and holds that strict lead‑paint liability alone is insufficient. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about repeated failure to repair leaky ceilings and water damage constituting a breach and warranting statutory damages.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof)… Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…”}

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: In *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–03, the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s failure to correct chronic flooding and sewer backups, after notice, was sufficient to establish a breach of quiet enjoyment, even absent an intent to harass, because the landlord’s inaction resulted in a serious interference with the tenant’s tenancy.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and explicitly rejects the need to prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights. The court holds that malicious intent is not required and that, at least where the landlord’s conduct is reckless, repeated failure to correct unsanitary flooding that seriously interferes with the tenant’s use of the premises constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment. This matches the proposition that chronic flooding and sewer backups after notice can establish a breach even absent intent to harass, based on serious interference with the tenancy.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct — failure to provide services and interference with quiet enjoyment — were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’… In 1973, the statute was rewritten… landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment… The common law background… also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.… [W]e hold that… Nor must the tenant prove that the landlord intended to interfere with the tenant’s rights, at least as long as the landlord’s conduct was reckless.”}

The opinion focuses on the landlord’s omissions, in the face of notice and tenant complaints, as potentially constituting a “serious interference” with tenancy and remands for fact-finding on whether those failures breached G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment… We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” as well as costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee. See also *Cruz Mgmt. Co.*, 417 Mass. at 788; *Al‑Ziab*, 424 Mass. at 852.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes and applies the remedial language of G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and a reasonable attorney’s fee. The court finds a § 14 violation on the facts and explicitly orders that Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on that basis, thereby affirming the proposition about the scope of statutory remedies under § 14.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” … On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.

*Hemingway v. L. c. 272, § 53, cannot constitutionally be the basis for criminal convictions for the use of offensive and abusive language.”
